content: No need for recursion. A simple "while" loop with an index for purchase counts does the job !
Added "write answer" to stub generator.

fix:
- typos
+ constraints

Moreover, I do not see where to use backtracking here. A direct recursion does the job quite well already. Did backtracking have something to do with Rule 2 (which was removed)?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I have done this nice puzzle with the itertools product function in python and  it took me  less than 15 minutes to get the solution but of course it is seriously not the best way to solve this problem. I should try the backtracking like Regulus136 for other languages.

Please add constraints.

Rule 2 is still not used. Either delete it or add a test&validator case where combinations of 11+ products need to be excluded.

"Rule 2 : Total number of products you can buy is 10"
There is no use of this rule in puzzle. You can add test where 11 or more products sum to voucher value.

Authors solution has time out in test 6. After couple of tries. Not always but it should be solid solution.

You can define max n in statement.

In python, validator 6 has some problem with floats when you sum them. I had to round it to third place to pass validator. It does not occur in other tests. I know it's flustrating for players, when all tests working and single validator is not. 
Don't have much advice how to prevent it, beside use only integers in input.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle. I agree with the validators. I solved the puzzle with backtracking. Maybe you can add some tags to this puzzle (like https://www.codingame.com/learn/backtracking)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun puzzle!

I get different answers for the last two tests and validators.  Validator #4 is easy to verify manually, should be 65 if I understand the problem correctly.

3+1 => 5*4=20
2+2 = >10
2+1+1 => 5*6=30
1+1+1+1=> 5
tot=65

Goal section
* Typo: "combinaison" and "combinaisons" should be corrected as "combinations", except for the last line "1 combination".

Input section
* Please specify the currencies (e.g. euro) for all line descriptions where applicable.
* Please follow the example to present the inputs, specifying line numbers and variable types:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement#guidelines

Test cases / validators
* Please fix the following issues with the names:
  - 3 "copies" instead of 3 "copy"
  - different "products" instead of different "product"
  - "little" money instead of "few" money

Thanks.
Thanks for your remarks, I did the corrections
Thank you very much for testing my puzzle and point out my mistakes. So yes you are right. I corrected my code and now it should be fine.

tag added: backtracking
Thank you for the approval.

actually, the rule 2: that limits the number of products to buy is important, it prevent from time out I think... When you try the combinations... I think if you add a condition saying: max number of products is 10. then some combinations will be rejected and then it should be fine.

I understand the frustration regarding rounded values and you are right if we put only integer then there is no more issue with that. But I prefer to keep it like that because it is reflecting a real situation that may happen in life. Actually, when I was student, I had to face to this type of situations... So it reminds me when I was young and it is the reason why I built that puzzle at first place.
You are right, I removed the second rule.
Thank you very much

Yes probably, backtracking is link to rule 2 which has been removed.
I added backtracking to answer to regulus136 see below... But maybe it is no more useful now.

And thank you for fixes.

There is no performance issue without limiting products count to 10 in such slow language as pure python.
Real situation - you have voucher and try to buy 11 products,  avoiding limit.

The problem in validator 6,  can't be easly debuged by human. I suggest swap test and validator 6 to let players face problem in test mode. Ideally would be better test float problem in smaller test.

yes sorry you are right regarding limit of 10 Versus performance issue, there is no link.... 
Real situation: you don't want to buy 10 times (or more ) the same product... 1 or 2 green salad is enough, 10 or more.... there is no sense. 
For debugging, you can try my code and uncomment line 95. So you will see the list of products.

Hi again,
I swap the 2 last tests : test 6 and test 6 validator...
So the more difficult is now the test 6 where you can trouble shoot if you can't find the solution. 
The validator for test 6 is now easier than test 6. 
I hope it will help and avoid to be stuck at the validator test where you can't see details...

In fact if  you are in "real situation" as you say, all prices have maximum two digits after decimals (at least in EuroZone), so if you multiply all prices by 100 you have integer.

So you can give price in cents and the problème is as in real life.

ok, I converted all value in cents... (x100)
So we deal with integer only !
Hmmm, now we match except the last validator I get 11 instead of 12.

Here are my combinations for last validator: 
[[dark chocolate bar 		: 2.3*1], [milk chocolate bar 		: 1.8*1], [pasta 500g 		: 1.9*1], [pepper 		: 1.0*2]]
[[dark chocolate bar 		: 2.3*1], [quinoa 500g 		: 3.5*1], [tomato sauce 250ml 		: 2.2*1]]
[[dark chocolate bar 		: 2.3*1], [mustard 200g 		: 2.5*1], [pepper 		: 1.0*1], [tomato sauce 250ml 		: 2.2*1]]
[[dark chocolate bar 		: 2.3*1], [ham 100g 		: 3.8*1], [pasta 500g 		: 1.9*1]]
[[pepper 		: 1.0*1], [quinoa 500g 		: 3.5*2]]
[[ham 100g 		: 3.8*1], [pepper 		: 1.0*2], [tomato sauce 250ml 		: 2.2*1]]
[[mustard 200g 		: 2.5*2], [pepper 		: 1.0*3]]
[[mustard 200g 		: 2.5*1], [pepper 		: 1.0*2], [quinoa 500g 		: 3.5*1]]
[[pack of 6 eggs 		: 1.55*2], [pasta 500g 		: 1.9*1], [pepper 		: 1.0*3]]
[[milk chocolate bar 		: 1.8*2], [mustard 200g 		: 2.5*1], [pasta 500g 		: 1.9*1]]
[[milk chocolate bar 		: 1.8*2], [tomato sauce 250ml 		: 2.2*2]]
[[pasta 500g 		: 1.9*2], [pepper 		: 1.0*2], [tomato sauce 250ml 		: 2.2*1]]

so 12 different possibilities.

You can check the same if you test my code and uncomment the line 88 that is showing list of products (so the list of combinations )

Okay, I had a bug but now I get 13.  What about 

[[dark chocolate bar : 2.3*1], [pasta 500g :1.9*3]]

Ok, this time, it is my bad.
I corrected again my code I think you are right, correct answer for last test is 13. So we are aligned now !
Thank you for the corrections. Please also standardise the variable name: either [[n]] or [[N]] in the Input section.
